awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Australia
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds Emanuel G. Indrei of The University of Texas at Austin to conduct a research project in mathematics, entitled "Investigating strategies that optimize the partial allocation of resources" during the summer of 2012 at Australian National University in Canberra ACT, Australia.  The host scientist is Prof. Neil Trudinger.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the investigation of free boundary regularity for the partial optimal transport problem. This problem is a generalization of the classical Monge-Kantorovich problem in which one tries to find a strategy of allocating a given number of resources as cheaply as possible. The research seeks an understanding of the regularity of this optimal strategy. The natural setting for this work is the field of partial differential equations and convex geometry, more specifically, the study of a double obstacle problem for the Monge-Ampère equation.  

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

por.por_cntn:
My favorite heuristic formulation of the classical optimal transport problem goes as follows: given a pile of sand and a hole of the same volume, one is tasked with transporting the sand into the hole as cheaply as possible. This is achieved by first specifying a cost function, c, so that the cost of transporting a grain of sand x to a point in the hole y is c(x,y) dollars. Then, the objective is to find a function T that minimizes the total cost of transporting the entire pile of sand into the hole (i.e. the ``sum" of c(x,T(x)) as x ranges through the pile of sand cannot be made smaller by a different function -- so T is in this sense the ``optimal transport"). 

This mathematical problem has a long and beautiful history with deep connections to economics and physics. Moreover, it has also been used by applied mathematicians in the field of medical image processing and has found many other interesting real-world applications.

In the partial transport problem, one is interested in moving only a fraction of the sand, say 20%, in a cost-effective way, and the ``free boundary" is precisely the mathematical object which identifies this region; the research I conducted as an NSF EAPSI fellow deals with understanding the geometry of the free boundary for a general class of cost functions.

More specifically, my results provide a solution to a technical problem previously discussed in the mathematical literature. At the heuristic level, it states that for many different cost functions, the free boundary is not too wiggly. This implies that the region making up the 20% to be transported looks somewhat ``nice." In practice, identifying the optimal region is a very difficult problem; however, knowing that the free boundary is somewhat well-behaved (i.e. not too wiggly) may lead to efficient algorithms used to identify the optimal 20% of sand to be transported. Of course, the sand/hole formulation was only a heuristic interpretation of the mathematical problem. There are many other possible ways of giving meaning to the optimal transfer of mass. Hence, there are numerous possible applications of this theory (e.g. how to partially allocate a given number of resources cheaply).    

The NSF EAPSI program provided me with a unique opportunity to interact with a world-class Australian mathematician -- Prof. Neil Trudinger -- at the Australian National University. Several years ago, he developed tools which turned out to be extremely useful for my problem. Moreover, I was able to present my research findings at a conference in Canberra, and also attend a winter school at the University of Queensland. Part of the research I conducted has already been published, and another portion is soon to follow. I was proud to represent my country abroad through the NSF EAPSI program.
